jdrasil.sat

Class Formula

  • java.lang.Object
    • jdrasil.sat.Formula
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>>

    public class Formula
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>>
    This class represents a formula of propositional logic in CNF. It provides methods to build, modify, and concatenate formulas.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      class  Formula.NoModelAvailableException
      This exception is used when one tries to get a model of the formula, but there is non.
      class  Formula.NoSATSolverRegisteredException
      This exception indicates that there is no SATSolver registered for this Formula.
      class  Formula.SATSolverRegisteredException
      This exception that there is a SATSolver registered for this Formula, and it was tried to modify the formula in an unsupported way, i.e., deleting or modifying a clause.

      void addAtLeast(int k, java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> variables)

      • canRegisterSATSolver

        public static boolean canRegisterSATSolver()

        Returns:

      • addVariable

        public void addVariable(int var)
        This method adds a variable the formula and updates the range of available variables. The method is automatically called when a clause is added, so it usually does not has to be called manually. However, sometimes one wishes to "register" and variable before we use it. In this case this method is useful.
        Parameters:
        var -

      • newVariable

        public int newVariable()
        Works as @see addVariable, but finds a safe variable number by it self and returns the new variable.
        Returns:

      • newAuxillaryVariable

        public int newAuxillaryVariable()
        Works as @see addVariable, but finds a safe variable number by it self and returns the new variable. Marks the variable as auxiliary was well.
        Returns:

      • addClause

        public void addClause(java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> C)
        Add a clause to the formula. If a SATSolver is registered, this will also transfer the clause directly to the solver.

      • removeClause

        public void removeClause(java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> C)
                  throws Formula.SATSolverRegisteredException
        Removes the given clause from the formula. If this will remove all occurrences of a variable in the clause, the variable will be removed from the formula as well. This method may increase the solution space of the formula and can only be called if no SAT solver is registered already. If there is SAT solver registered an exception will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        C -
        Throws:
        Formula.SATSolverRegisteredException

      • addAtMost

        public void addAtMost(int k,
                      java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> variables)
        Adds an at-most-k constraint to the formula with respect to the given set of variables, i.e., only models that set not more the k of the given variables of true can satisfy the formula.
        Parameters:
        k -
        variables -

      • addAtLeast

        public void addAtLeast(int k,
                       java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> variables)
        Adds an at-least-k constraint to the formula with respect to the given set of variables, i.e., only models that set k ore more of the given variables of true can satisfy the formula.
        Parameters:
        k -
        variables -

      • addCardinalityConstraint

        public void addCardinalityConstraint(int lb,
                                     int ub,
                                     java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> variables)
        Adds an cardinality constraint to the formula with respect to the given set of variables, i.e., only models that set a least lb and at most ub of the variables to true can satisfy the formula. This function uses an encoding based on sorting networks and is well suited for iterative calls, i.e., a second call that increases lb or decreases ub (or both) will add much less new clauses. In contrast @see addAtMost() and @see addAtLeast() are better for single calls. This methods adds O(n*log^2 n) variables to the formula, so it is also worth for big k.
        Parameters:
        lb -
        ub -
        variables -

      • addDecreasingAtMost

        public void addDecreasingAtMost(int k,
                                java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> variables)
        At an atMostK constraint that can be decreased between calls to the SAT solver. This method works similar as @see addCardinalityConstraint(), but does only support atMostK-constraints. It adds O(k*n) variables to the formula, so it is only valuable for small k.
        Parameters:
        k -
        variables -

      • assumeCardinalityConstraint

        public void assumeCardinalityConstraint(int lb,
                                        int ub,
                                        java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> variables)
                                 throws Formula.NoSATSolverRegisteredException
        Works as @see addCardinalityConstraint, but does add the lb and ub only as assumption (auxillary variables and clauses are added normaly, so that this method can be used incrementally as well). As this method does make an assumption, it only works if a SAT solver is registered (other wise a @see NoSATSolverRegisteredException will be thrown).
        Parameters:
        lb -
        ub -
        variables -
        Throws:
        Formula.NoSATSolverRegisteredException

      • registerSATSolver

        public java.lang.String registerSATSolver()
                                   throws ISATSolver.SATSolverNotAvailableException
        Register a SAT solver to the formula. Registering a solver means the following: 1) the formula will be send to the solver 2) any newly added clause will be send to the solver (i.e., they will be in sync) 3) deletion or modification of clauses is not possible until the solver was unregistered 4) @see isSatisfiable() can be used to check (using the registered solver) if the formula is satisfiable 5) the last point can be used incrementally The user has no influence on which kind of solver will be registered. You can check whether or not this method will throw an exception with @see canRegisterSATSolver()
        Returns:
        String the signature of the loaded solver
        Throws:
        ISATSolver.SATSolverNotAvailableException - if Jdrasil has no access to any SATSolver

      • unregisterSATSolver

        public void unregisterSATSolver()
        Unregisters the SAT solver, if set. This means: 1) The Formula and the solver will not be in sync anymore 2) Clauses can be modified again 3) @see isSatisfiable() will throw an Exception until a new solver is registerd.

      • isSatisfiable

        public boolean isSatisfiable(java.lang.Integer... assumption)
                      throws Formula.NoSATSolverRegisteredException
        Use a SAT solver to check if there is a satisfying model for the formula. If this method returns true, i.e., if the formula is satisfiable, a satisfying model will be stored, i.e., @see getModel() can be called afterwards.
        Returns:
        true if the formula is satisfiable
        Throws:
        Formula.NoSATSolverRegisteredException - if no SAT solver was registered for this formula

      • getModel

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.Boolean> getModel()
                                                            throws Formula.NoModelAvailableException
        If the formula is satisfiable, this method can be used to obtain a model. A model will only be available if @see isSatisfiable() was called and has returned true. The model will correspond to the last (successful) call of @see isSatisfiable().
        Returns:
        Throws:
        Formula.NoModelAvailableException
